description: A dataset examining the relationship between social media usage metrics and changes in suicide rates since 2010. The dataset combines social media engagement statistics with World Health Organization (WHO) suicide rate data to analyze potential correlations between digital platform usage and changes in suicide prevalence.

original_source.creator: Unknown/Not Specified
original_source.institution: Likely compiled from WHO and social media platform data

columns.name: social_media_usage
columns.semantic_description: Likely represents the percentage of population using social media platforms or average time spent on social media

columns.name: engagement_metrics
columns.semantic_description: Measures of user interaction such as likes, shares, or comments on social platforms

columns.name: platform_penetration
columns.semantic_description: Market penetration or adoption rate of specific social media platforms in the population

columns.name: demographic_factor
columns.semantic_description: Demographic variables that might influence both social media usage and suicide rates

columns.name: temporal_metric
columns.semantic_description: Time-based measurement, possibly year or period of observation

target_description.name: suicide_rate_change_since_2010
target_description.meaning: Percentage change in suicide rates compared to 2010 baseline levels

dataset_history: This dataset appears to be compiled as part of a broader investigation into the relationship between social media usage and mental health outcomes. It combines WHO suicide statistics with social media metrics, using 2010 as a baseline year, likely chosen because it represents a period when social media usage began to accelerate globally.
inference_notes:
Important considerations:
1. Small sample size (30 instances) limits statistical power
2. Correlation does not imply causation - many confounding variables may exist
3. Social media metrics may be aggregated across platforms
4. Geographic and cultural factors may not be fully captured
5. Reporting biases in suicide statistics vary by country/region
6. Social media usage data may have collection inconsistencies
7. The 2010 baseline choice may affect interpretation of trends
